user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_GenericBinSemTake_Impl:
```c
static int32 OS_GenericBinSemTake_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const struct timespec *timeout)
{
    sig_atomic_t                      flush_count;
    int32                             return_code;
    OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t *sem;

    sem = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_bin_sem_table, *token);

    /*
     * Note - this lock should be quickly available - should not delay here.
     * The main delay is in the pthread_cond_wait() below.
     */
    /* Lock the mutex ( not the table! ) */
    if (OS_Posix_BinSemAcquireMutex(&sem->id) != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    /* because pthread_cond_wait() is also a cancellation point,
     * this uses a cleanup handler to ensure that if canceled during this call,
     * the mutex is also released */
    pthread_cleanup_push(OS_Posix_BinSemReleaseMutex, &sem->id);

    return_code = OS_SUCCESS;

    /*
     * Note that for vxWorks compatibility, we need to stop pending on the semaphore
     * and return from this function under two possible circumstances:
     *
     *  a) the semaphore count was nonzero (may be pre-existing or due to a give)
     *     this is the normal case, we should decrement the count by 1 and return.
     *  b) the semaphore got "flushed"
     *     in this case ALL tasks are un-blocked and we do NOT decrement the count.
     */

    /*
     * first take a local snapshot of the flush request counter,
     * if it changes, we know that someone else called SemFlush.
     */
    flush_count = sem->flush_request;

    /* Note - the condition must be checked in a while loop because
     * even if pthread_cond_wait() returns, it does NOT guarantee that
     * the condition we are looking for has been met.
     *
     * Also if the current_value is already nonzero we will not wait.
     */
    while (sem->current_value == 0 && sem->flush_request == flush_count)
    {
        /* Must pend until something changes */
        if (timeout == NULL)
        {
            /* wait forever */
            pthread_cond_wait(&(sem->cv), &(sem->id));
        }
        else if (pthread_cond_timedwait(&(sem->cv), &(sem->id), timeout) == ETIMEDOUT)
        {
            return_code = OS_SEM_TIMEOUT;
            break;
        }
    }

    /* If the flush counter did not change, set the value to zero */
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS && sem->flush_request == flush_count)
    {
        sem->current_value = 0;
    }

    /*
     * Pop the cleanup handler.
     * Passing "true" means it will be executed, which
     * handles releasing the mutex.
     */
    pthread_cleanup_pop(true);

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_GenericBinSemTake_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t OS_impl_bin_sem_table[OS_MAX_BIN_SEMAPHORES]
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t       id;
    pthread_cond_t        cv;
    volatile sig_atomic_t flush_request;
    volatile sig_atomic_t current_value;
} OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
int32 OS_Posix_BinSemAcquireMutex(pthread_mutex_t *mut)
{
    struct timespec timeout;

    if (clock_gettime(CLOCK_REALTIME, &timeout) != 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    timeout.tv_sec += OS_POSIX_BINSEM_MAX_WAIT_SECONDS;

    if (pthread_mutex_timedlock(mut, &timeout) != 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
void OS_Posix_BinSemReleaseMutex(void *mut)
{
    pthread_mutex_unlock(mut);
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_SEM_FAILURE (-6)
...
#define OS_SEM_TIMEOUT (-7)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no uses of compiler-specific language extensions in the provided code. In particular:
- There are no GCC/Clang/MSVC extension constructs such as __attribute__, __asm__, __builtin_*, typeof, statement expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, labels-as-values, or other vendor-specific keywords.
- pthread_* calls (pthread_cond_wait, pthread_cond_timedwait, pthread_mutex_timedlock, pthread_cleanup_push/pop, pthread_mutex_unlock) are POSIX API calls/macros (library usage), not compiler language extensions as required by Rule 1.2 in this task; their use does not by itself indicate a compiler language extension documented as such.
- The pthread_cleanup_push/pthread_cleanup_pop are POSIX macros that must be paired in the same lexical scope; they are not compiler language extensions in the sense required by this rule.
- The conversion of void* (OS_Posix_BinSemReleaseMutex parameter) to pthread_mutex_t* when calling pthread_mutex_unlock is permitted in C (void* -> object pointer conversions are allowed), so this is not a compiler extension.
- Use of sig_atomic_t, volatile, typedefs, macros, and other standard C constructs is standard C and not an extension.

Therefore there are no code fragments that require investigation for compiler language extensions per MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 as scoped in your instruction.
